Martin Luther was a theologian, reformer, and translator of the Bible into German. He had a profound influence on the development of the German language and on the study of word meanings.

Luther was particularly interested in the study of biblical Hebrew and Greek, as he believed that a correct understanding of the original languages was essential for the interpretation of scripture. He wrote extensively on the importance of studying the languages of the Bible and the nuances of word meanings in these languages.

For example, in his preface to the German translation of the New Testament (1522), Luther argued that the Greek word "metanoia" (translated as "repentance" in English) should be understood as a change of heart and mind, rather than just a superficial act of remorse. He emphasized the importance of understanding the original Greek meaning of the word in order to fully grasp the concept of repentance in the Bible.

Luther also believed that language was closely tied to culture and history. In his work "On Translating" (1530), he emphasized the need to understand the cultural and historical context of a text in order to accurately translate its meaning into another language. He believed that a translator should have a deep knowledge of both the source and target languages, as well as the cultures that they are embedded in, in order to accurately convey the intended meaning of a text.

In summary, Martin Luther's view on the study of word meanings emphasized the importance of studying the original languages of the Bible, understanding the cultural and historical context of a text, and accurately conveying its intended meaning in translation.
